trans-unit.source: .NET multi-tier application | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: .NET multi-tier application | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that helps you develop a multi-tier app in Azure that uses Service Bus queues to communicate between tiers. Samples in .NET.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that helps you develop a multi-tier app in Azure that uses Service Bus queues to communicate between tiers. Samples in .NET.

trans-unit.source: .NET multi-tier application using Azure Service Bus queues
trans-unit.target: .NET multi-tier application using Azure Service Bus queues

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Developing for Microsoft Azure is easy using Visual Studio 2013 and the free Azure SDK for .NET.
trans-unit.target: Developing for Microsoft Azure is easy using Visual Studio 2013 and the free Azure SDK for .NET.

trans-unit.source: If you do not already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK will automatically install Visual Studio Express, so you can start developing for Azure entirely for
trans-unit.target: If you do not already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK will automatically install Visual Studio Express, so you can start developing for Azure entirely for

trans-unit.source: free.
trans-unit.target: free.

trans-unit.source: This article assumes you have no prior experience using Azure.
trans-unit.target: This article assumes you have no prior experience using Azure.

trans-unit.source: After completing this tutorial, you will have an application that uses
trans-unit.target: After completing this tutorial, you will have an application that uses

trans-unit.source: multiple Azure resources running in your local environment and
trans-unit.target: multiple Azure resources running in your local environment and

trans-unit.source: that demonstrates how a multi-tier application works.
trans-unit.target: that demonstrates how a multi-tier application works.

trans-unit.source: You will learn:
trans-unit.target: You will learn:

trans-unit.source: How to enable your computer for Azure development with a
trans-unit.target: How to enable your computer for Azure development with a

trans-unit.source: single download and install.
trans-unit.target: single download and install.

trans-unit.source: How to use Visual Studio to develop for Azure.
trans-unit.target: How to use Visual Studio to develop for Azure.

trans-unit.source: How to create a multi-tier application in Azure using web
trans-unit.target: How to create a multi-tier application in Azure using web

trans-unit.source: and worker roles.
trans-unit.target: and worker roles.

trans-unit.source: How to communicate between tiers using Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: How to communicate between tiers using Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you'll build and run the multi-tier application in an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you'll build and run the multi-tier application in an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The front end will be an ASP.NET MVC web role and the back end will be a worker-role.
trans-unit.target: The front end will be an ASP.NET MVC web role and the back end will be a worker-role.

trans-unit.source: You can create the same multi-tier application with the front end as a web project that is deployed to an Azure website instead of a cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You can create the same multi-tier application with the front end as a web project that is deployed to an Azure website instead of a cloud service.

trans-unit.source: For instructions about what to do differently on an Azure website front end, see the <link><linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title></link> section.
trans-unit.target: For instructions about what to do differently on an Azure website front end, see the <link><linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title></link> section.

trans-unit.source: The following screen shot shows the completed application.
trans-unit.target: The following screen shot shows the completed application.

trans-unit.source: Azure also provides storage queue functionality.
trans-unit.target: Azure also provides storage queue functionality.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure storage queues and Service Bus queues, see <link><linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues - Compared and Contrasted[sbqueuecomparison]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure storage queues and Service Bus queues, see <link><linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues - Compared and Contrasted[sbqueuecomparison]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Scenario overview: Inter-role communication
trans-unit.target: Scenario overview: Inter-role communication

trans-unit.source: To submit an order for processing, the front end UI component, running
trans-unit.target: To submit an order for processing, the front end UI component, running

trans-unit.source: in the web role, needs to interact with the middle tier logic running in
trans-unit.target: in the web role, needs to interact with the middle tier logic running in

trans-unit.source: the worker role.
trans-unit.target: the worker role.

trans-unit.source: This example uses Service Bus brokered messaging for
trans-unit.target: This example uses Service Bus brokered messaging for

trans-unit.source: the communication between the tiers.
trans-unit.target: the communication between the tiers.

trans-unit.source: Using brokered messaging between the web and middle tiers decouples the
trans-unit.target: Using brokered messaging between the web and middle tiers decouples the

trans-unit.source: two components.
trans-unit.target: two components.

trans-unit.source: In contrast to direct messaging (that is, TCP or HTTP),
trans-unit.target: In contrast to direct messaging (that is, TCP or HTTP),

trans-unit.source: the web tier does not connect to the middle tier directly; instead it
trans-unit.target: the web tier does not connect to the middle tier directly; instead it

trans-unit.source: pushes units of work, as messages, into the Service Bus, which reliably
trans-unit.target: pushes units of work, as messages, into the Service Bus, which reliably

trans-unit.source: retains them until the middle tier is ready to consume and process them.
trans-unit.target: retains them until the middle tier is ready to consume and process them.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides two entities to support brokered messaging:
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides two entities to support brokered messaging:

trans-unit.source: queues and topics.
trans-unit.target: queues and topics.

trans-unit.source: With queues, each message sent to the queue is
trans-unit.target: With queues, each message sent to the queue is

trans-unit.source: consumed by a single receiver.
trans-unit.target: consumed by a single receiver.

trans-unit.source: Topics support the publish/subscribe
trans-unit.target: Topics support the publish/subscribe

trans-unit.source: pattern in which each published message is made available to a subscription registered with the topic.
trans-unit.target: pattern in which each published message is made available to a subscription registered with the topic.

trans-unit.source: Each subscription logically
trans-unit.target: Each subscription logically

trans-unit.source: maintains its own queue of messages.
trans-unit.target: maintains its own queue of messages.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions can also be
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions can also be

trans-unit.source: configured with filter rules that restrict the set of messages passed to
trans-unit.target: configured with filter rules that restrict the set of messages passed to

trans-unit.source: the subscription queue to those that match the filter.
trans-unit.target: the subscription queue to those that match the filter.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses
trans-unit.target: The following example uses

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: This communication mechanism has several advantages over direct
trans-unit.target: This communication mechanism has several advantages over direct

trans-unit.source: messaging:
trans-unit.target: messaging:

trans-unit.source: Temporal decoupling. With the asynchronous messaging pattern,
trans-unit.target: Temporal decoupling. With the asynchronous messaging pattern,

trans-unit.source: producers and consumers need not be online at the same time.
trans-unit.target: producers and consumers need not be online at the same time.

trans-unit.source: Service
trans-unit.target: Service

trans-unit.source: Bus reliably stores messages until the consuming party is ready to
trans-unit.target: Bus reliably stores messages until the consuming party is ready to

trans-unit.source: receive them.
trans-unit.target: receive them.

trans-unit.source: This allows the components of the distributed
trans-unit.target: This allows the components of the distributed

trans-unit.source: application to be disconnected, either voluntarily, for example, for
trans-unit.target: application to be disconnected, either voluntarily, for example, for

trans-unit.source: maintenance, or due to a component crash, without impacting the
trans-unit.target: maintenance, or due to a component crash, without impacting the

trans-unit.source: system as a whole.
trans-unit.target: system as a whole.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, the consuming application may only
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, the consuming application may only

trans-unit.source: need to come online during certain times of the day.
trans-unit.target: need to come online during certain times of the day.

trans-unit.source: Load leveling. In many applications, system load varies over
trans-unit.target: Load leveling. In many applications, system load varies over

trans-unit.source: time, while the processing time required for each unit of work is
trans-unit.target: time, while the processing time required for each unit of work is

trans-unit.source: typically constant.
trans-unit.target: typically constant.

trans-unit.source: Intermediating message producers and consumers
trans-unit.target: Intermediating message producers and consumers

trans-unit.source: with a queue means that the consuming application (the worker) only needs to be provisioned to accommodate average load rather than peak
trans-unit.target: with a queue means that the consuming application (the worker) only needs to be provisioned to accommodate average load rather than peak

trans-unit.source: load.
trans-unit.target: load.

trans-unit.source: The depth of the queue will grow and contract as the incoming
trans-unit.target: The depth of the queue will grow and contract as the incoming

trans-unit.source: load varies.
trans-unit.target: load varies.

trans-unit.source: This directly saves money in terms of the amount of
trans-unit.target: This directly saves money in terms of the amount of

trans-unit.source: infrastructure required to service the application load.
trans-unit.target: infrastructure required to service the application load.

trans-unit.source: Load balancing. As load increases, more worker processes can be
trans-unit.target: Load balancing. As load increases, more worker processes can be

trans-unit.source: added to read from the queue.
trans-unit.target: added to read from the queue.

trans-unit.source: Each message is processed by only one
trans-unit.target: Each message is processed by only one

trans-unit.source: of the worker processes.
trans-unit.target: of the worker processes.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, this pull-based load balancing
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, this pull-based load balancing

trans-unit.source: allows for optimum utilization of the worker machines even if the
trans-unit.target: allows for optimum utilization of the worker machines even if the

trans-unit.source: worker machines differ in terms of processing power as they will
trans-unit.target: worker machines differ in terms of processing power as they will

trans-unit.source: pull messages at their own maximum rate.
trans-unit.target: pull messages at their own maximum rate.

trans-unit.source: This pattern is often
trans-unit.target: This pattern is often

trans-unit.source: termed the competing consumer pattern.
trans-unit.target: termed the competing consumer pattern.

trans-unit.source: The following sections discuss the code that implements this architecture.
trans-unit.target: The following sections discuss the code that implements this architecture.

trans-unit.source: Set up the development environment
trans-unit.target: Set up the development environment

trans-unit.source: Before you can begin developing your Azure application, download the tools and set up your development environment:
trans-unit.target: Before you can begin developing your Azure application, download the tools and set up your development environment:

trans-unit.source: To install the Azure SDK for .NET, click the following link.
trans-unit.target: To install the Azure SDK for .NET, click the following link.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Get Tools and SDK[]</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Get Tools and SDK[]</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Click the link for the version of Visual Studio you are using.
trans-unit.target: Click the link for the version of Visual Studio you are using.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this tutorial use Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this tutorial use Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: When prompted to run or save the installation file, click
trans-unit.target: When prompted to run or save the installation file, click

trans-unit.source: Run.
trans-unit.target: Run.

trans-unit.source: In the Web Platform Installer, click Install and proceed with the installation.
trans-unit.target: In the Web Platform Installer, click Install and proceed with the installation.

trans-unit.source: Once the installation is complete, you have everything
trans-unit.target: Once the installation is complete, you have everything

trans-unit.source: necessary to start developing the app.
trans-unit.target: necessary to start developing the app.

trans-unit.source: The SDK includes tools that enable you
trans-unit.target: The SDK includes tools that enable you

trans-unit.source: to develop Azure applications in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: to develop Azure applications in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: If you
trans-unit.target: If you

trans-unit.source: do not have Visual Studio installed, it also installs the free
trans-unit.target: do not have Visual Studio installed, it also installs the free

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio Express for Web.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio Express for Web.

trans-unit.source: Set up the Service Bus namespace
trans-unit.target: Set up the Service Bus namespace

trans-unit.source: The next step is to create a service namespace, and to obtain a Shared Access Signature (SAS) key.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to create a service namespace, and to obtain a Shared Access Signature (SAS) key.

trans-unit.source: A service namespace provides an application boundary for
trans-unit.target: A service namespace provides an application boundary for

trans-unit.source: each application exposed through Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: each application exposed through Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: A SAS key is
trans-unit.target: A SAS key is

trans-unit.source: generated by the system when a service namespace is
trans-unit.target: generated by the system when a service namespace is

trans-unit.source: created.
trans-unit.target: created.

trans-unit.source: The combination of service namespace and SAS key
trans-unit.target: The combination of service namespace and SAS key

trans-unit.source: provides the credentials for Service Bus to authenticate access to an
trans-unit.target: provides the credentials for Service Bus to authenticate access to an

trans-unit.source: application.
trans-unit.target: application.

trans-unit.source: You can also manage namespaces and Service Bus messaging entities using the Visual Studio Server Explorer, but you can only create new namespaces from within the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: You can also manage namespaces and Service Bus messaging entities using the Visual Studio Server Explorer, but you can only create new namespaces from within the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Set up the namespace using the Azure portal
trans-unit.target: Set up the namespace using the Azure portal

trans-unit.source: Log into the <link><linkText>Azure portal[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Log into the <link><linkText>Azure portal[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane of the Azure portal, click
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane of the Azure portal, click

trans-unit.source: Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: In the lower pane of the Azure portal, click Create.
trans-unit.target: In the lower pane of the Azure portal, click Create.

trans-unit.source: In the Add a new namespace page, enter a namespace name.
trans-unit.target: In the Add a new namespace page, enter a namespace name.

trans-unit.source: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.
trans-unit.target: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.

trans-unit.source: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the
trans-unit.target: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the

trans-unit.source: country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make
trans-unit.target: country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make

trans-unit.source: sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your
trans-unit.target: sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your

trans-unit.source: compute resources).
trans-unit.target: compute resources).

trans-unit.source: Also, make sure that you select Messaging in the namespace Type field, and Standard in the Messaging Tier field.
trans-unit.target: Also, make sure that you select Messaging in the namespace Type field, and Standard in the Messaging Tier field.

trans-unit.source: Pick the same region that you intend to choose to
trans-unit.target: Pick the same region that you intend to choose to

trans-unit.source: deploy your application.
trans-unit.target: deploy your application.

trans-unit.source: This will give you the best performance.
trans-unit.target: This will give you the best performance.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: The system now creates your service
trans-unit.target: The system now creates your service

trans-unit.source: namespace and enables it.
trans-unit.target: namespace and enables it.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait several minutes as
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait several minutes as

trans-unit.target: the system provisions resources for your account.

trans-unit.source: In the main window, click the name of your service namespace.
trans-unit.target: In the main window, click the name of your service namespace.

trans-unit.source: Click Connection Information.
trans-unit.target: Click Connection Information.

trans-unit.source: In the Access connection information pane, find the connection string that contains the SAS key and key name.
trans-unit.target: In the Access connection information pane, find the connection string that contains the SAS key and key name.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of these credentials, or copy them to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of these credentials, or copy them to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: Cloud configuration manager
trans-unit.target: Cloud configuration manager

trans-unit.source: The GetSettings method in the
trans-unit.target: The GetSettings method in the

trans-unit.source: Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Configuration.CloudConfigurationManager class
trans-unit.target: Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Configuration.CloudConfigurationManager class

trans-unit.source: enables you to read configuration settings from the configuration store for your
trans-unit.target: enables you to read configuration settings from the configuration store for your

trans-unit.source: platform.
trans-unit.target: platform.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your code is running
trans-unit.target: For example, if your code is running

trans-unit.source: in a web or worker role the GetSettings method reads the
trans-unit.target: in a web or worker role the GetSettings method reads the

trans-unit.source: ServiceConfiguration.cscfg file, and if your code is running in a standard
trans-unit.target: ServiceConfiguration.cscfg file, and if your code is running in a standard

trans-unit.source: console app the GetSettings method reads the app.config file.
trans-unit.target: console app the GetSettings method reads the app.config file.

trans-unit.source: If you store a connection string for your Service Bus namespace in a
trans-unit.target: If you store a connection string for your Service Bus namespace in a

trans-unit.source: configuration file, you can use the GetSettings method to read a connection
trans-unit.target: configuration file, you can use the GetSettings method to read a connection

trans-unit.source: string that you can use to instantiate a NamespaceMananger object.
trans-unit.target: string that you can use to instantiate a NamespaceMananger object.

trans-unit.source: You can
trans-unit.target: You can

trans-unit.source: use a NamespaceMananger instance to configure your Service Bus namespace
trans-unit.target: use a NamespaceMananger instance to configure your Service Bus namespace

trans-unit.source: programmatically.
trans-unit.target: programmatically.

trans-unit.source: You can use the same connection string to instantiate a client
trans-unit.target: You can use the same connection string to instantiate a client

trans-unit.source: objects (such as QueueClient, TopicClient, and EventHubClient
trans-unit.target: objects (such as QueueClient, TopicClient, and EventHubClient

trans-unit.source: object) that you can use to perform runtime operations such as sending and
trans-unit.target: object) that you can use to perform runtime operations such as sending and

trans-unit.source: receiving messages.
trans-unit.target: receiving messages.

trans-unit.source: Connection string
trans-unit.target: Connection string

trans-unit.source: To instantiate a client (for example, a Service Bus QueueClient), you can represent the configuration information as a connection string.
trans-unit.target: To instantiate a client (for example, a Service Bus QueueClient), you can represent the configuration information as a connection string.

trans-unit.source: On the client side, there is a CreateFromConnectionString() method that instantiates that client type by using that connection string.
trans-unit.target: On the client side, there is a CreateFromConnectionString() method that instantiates that client type by using that connection string.

trans-unit.source: For example, given the following configuration section
trans-unit.target: For example, given the following configuration section

trans-unit.target: The following code retrieves the connection string, creates a queue, and initializes the connection to the queue.

trans-unit.source: Create the worker role
trans-unit.target: Create the worker role

trans-unit.target: You will now create the worker role that processes the order

trans-unit.source: This example uses the Worker Role with Service Bus Queue Visual Studio project template.
trans-unit.target: This example uses the Worker Role with Service Bus Queue Visual Studio project template.

trans-unit.source: First, use Server Explorer in Visual Studio to obtain the required credentials.
trans-unit.target: First, use Server Explorer in Visual Studio to obtain the required credentials.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have connected Visual Studio to your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have connected Visual Studio to your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, in Solution Explorer right-click the
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, in Solution Explorer right-click the

trans-unit.source: Roles folder under the MultiTierApp project.
trans-unit.target: Roles folder under the MultiTierApp project.

trans-unit.source: Click Add, and then click New Worker Role Project.
trans-unit.target: Click Add, and then click New Worker Role Project.

trans-unit.source: The Add New Role Project dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The Add New Role Project dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Role Project dialog box, click Worker Role with Service Bus Queue.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Role Project dialog box, click Worker Role with Service Bus Queue.

trans-unit.source: In the Name box, name the project OrderProcessingRole.
trans-unit.target: In the Name box, name the project OrderProcessingRole.

trans-unit.source: Then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Then click Add.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, right-click the name of your service namespace, then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, right-click the name of your service namespace, then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio Properties pane, the first entry contains a connection string that is populated with the namespace endpoint containing the required authorization credentials.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio Properties pane, the first entry contains a connection string that is populated with the namespace endpoint containing the required authorization credentials.

trans-unit.source: For example, see the following screen shot.
trans-unit.target: For example, see the following screen shot.

trans-unit.source: Double-click ConnectionString, and then press Ctrl+C to copy this string to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Double-click ConnectionString, and then press Ctrl+C to copy this string to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the OrderProcessingRole you created in step 5 (make sure that you right-click OrderProcessingRole under Roles, and not the class).
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the OrderProcessingRole you created in step 5 (make sure that you right-click OrderProcessingRole under Roles, and not the class).

trans-unit.source: Then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: Then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: On the Settings tab of the Properties dialog box, click inside the Value box for Microsoft.ServiceBus.ConnectionString, and then paste the endpoint value you copied in step 6.
trans-unit.target: On the Settings tab of the Properties dialog box, click inside the Value box for Microsoft.ServiceBus.ConnectionString, and then paste the endpoint value you copied in step 6.

trans-unit.source: Create an OnlineOrder class to represent the orders as you process them from the queue.
trans-unit.target: Create an OnlineOrder class to represent the orders as you process them from the queue.

trans-unit.source: You can reuse a class you have already created.
trans-unit.target: You can reuse a class you have already created.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the OrderProcessingRole project (right-click the project, not the role).
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the OrderProcessingRole project (right-click the project, not the role).

trans-unit.source: Click Add, then click Existing Item.
trans-unit.target: Click Add, then click Existing Item.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the subfolder for FrontendWebRole\Models, and then double-click OnlineOrder.cs to add it to this project.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the subfolder for FrontendWebRole\Models, and then double-click OnlineOrder.cs to add it to this project.

trans-unit.source: In WorkerRole.cs, replace the value of the QueueName variable in WorkerRole.cs from "ProcessingQueue" to "OrdersQueue" as shown in the following code.
trans-unit.target: In WorkerRole.cs, replace the value of the QueueName variable in WorkerRole.cs from "ProcessingQueue" to "OrdersQueue" as shown in the following code.

trans-unit.source: Add the following using statement at the top of the WorkerRole.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Add the following using statement at the top of the WorkerRole.cs file.

trans-unit.source: In the Run() function, inside the OnMessage call, add the following code inside the try clause.
trans-unit.target: In the Run() function, inside the OnMessage call, add the following code inside the try clause.

trans-unit.source: You have completed the application.
trans-unit.target: You have completed the application.

trans-unit.source: You can test the full
trans-unit.target: You can test the full

trans-unit.source: application by right-clicking the MultiTierApp project in Solution Explorer,
trans-unit.target: application by right-clicking the MultiTierApp project in Solution Explorer,

trans-unit.source: selecting Set as Startup Project, and then pressing F5.
trans-unit.target: selecting Set as Startup Project, and then pressing F5.

trans-unit.source: Note that the
trans-unit.target: Note that the

trans-unit.source: message count does not increment, because the worker role processes items
trans-unit.target: message count does not increment, because the worker role processes items

trans-unit.source: from the queue and marks them as complete.
trans-unit.target: from the queue and marks them as complete.

trans-unit.source: You can see the trace output of
trans-unit.target: You can see the trace output of

trans-unit.source: your worker role by viewing the Azure Compute Emulator UI.
trans-unit.target: your worker role by viewing the Azure Compute Emulator UI.

trans-unit.source: You
trans-unit.target: You

trans-unit.source: can do this by right-clicking the emulator icon in the notification
trans-unit.target: can do this by right-clicking the emulator icon in the notification

trans-unit.source: area of your taskbar and selecting Show Compute Emulator UI.
trans-unit.target: area of your taskbar and selecting Show Compute Emulator UI.

trans-unit.source: You might want to implement the front-end of a multi-tier application in an Azure website instead of an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You might want to implement the front-end of a multi-tier application in an Azure website instead of an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the difference between websites and cloud services, see <link><linkText>Azure Execution Models[executionmodels]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the difference between websites and cloud services, see <link><linkText>Azure Execution Models[executionmodels]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To implement the application you create in this tutorial as a standard web project instead of as a cloud service web role, follow the steps in this tutorial with the following differences:
trans-unit.target: To implement the application you create in this tutorial as a standard web project instead of as a cloud service web role, follow the steps in this tutorial with the following differences:

trans-unit.source: When you create the project, choose the ASP.NET MVC Web Application project template in the Web category instead of the Cloud Service template in the Cloud category.
trans-unit.target: When you create the project, choose the ASP.NET MVC Web Application project template in the Web category instead of the Cloud Service template in the Cloud category.

trans-unit.source: Then follow the same directions for creating the MVC application, until you get to the Cloud configuration manager section.
trans-unit.target: Then follow the same directions for creating the MVC application, until you get to the Cloud configuration manager section.

trans-unit.source: When you create the worker role, create it in a new, separate solution, similar to the original instructions for the web role.
trans-unit.target: When you create the worker role, create it in a new, separate solution, similar to the original instructions for the web role.

trans-unit.source: Now however, you're creating just the worker role in the cloud service project.
trans-unit.target: Now however, you're creating just the worker role in the cloud service project.

trans-unit.source: Then follow the same directions for creating the worker role.
trans-unit.target: Then follow the same directions for creating the worker role.

trans-unit.source: You can test the front-end and back-end separately, or you can run both simultaneously in separate Visual Studio instances.
trans-unit.target: You can test the front-end and back-end separately, or you can run both simultaneously in separate Visual Studio instances.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to deploy the front end to an Azure website, see <link><linkText>Deploying an ASP.NET Web Application to an Azure Website</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to deploy the front end to an Azure website, see <link><linkText>Deploying an ASP.NET Web Application to an Azure Website</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to deploy the back end to an Azure cloud service, see <link><linkText>.NET Multi-Tier Application Using Storage Tables, Queues, and Blobs[mutitierstorage]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to deploy the back end to an Azure cloud service, see <link><linkText>.NET Multi-Tier Application Using Storage Tables, Queues, and Blobs[mutitierstorage]</linkText><title></title></link>.
